title: A Behavior Model for Persuasive Design
summary: Behavior happens when Motivation, Ability, and a Prompt converge. If a behavior doesn't happen, one of these three is missing. To increase behavior, it is often easier to increase Ability (make it simpler) than to increase Motivation.

effectiveness_metrics.description: Reducing friction/increasing ability is consistently more reliable than relying on willpower/motivation.

mechanisms.name: Ability/Simplicity
mechanisms.description: The easier a behavior is, the less motivation is required to do it.

mechanisms.name: Prompting
mechanisms.description: A trigger must occur *at the moment* the user has both the ability and motivation.

mechanisms.name: Tiny Habits
mechanisms.description: Scaling a behavior down to its smallest possible unit (e.g., 'floss one tooth') to bypass motivation hurdles.

actionable_strategies.name: Micro-Activity Scaling Template
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Algorithmically or manually break down any large user task into a <2 minute starter step. The goal is solely initiation, not completion.

actionable_strategies.name: Context-Aware Prompting
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Use system usage stats to detect 'low-focus' moments (e.g., rapid switching, idle time) to insert the prompt when cognitive load is naturally low.
